thread.title: Texas mascot BEVO XIV retires after cancer diagnosis
thread.title_full: Texas mascot BEVO XIV retires after cancer diagnosis - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Texas mascot BEVO XIV retires after cancer diagnosis
text:
Eric Gay/AP Texas mascot, Bevo, is sprayed with a mist to keep cool prior to a Sept. 26 game vs. Oklahoma State. BEVO XIV, the University of Texas mascot, has been diagnosed with Bovine Leukemia Virus and will retire immediately.
Originally named Sunrise Studly, the longhorn was given a preliminary diagnosis last week, according to the university's athletics website , and was recently confirmed by "top veterinarians." BEVO XIV will "rest comfortably" in the company of his owners and caretakers, John T. and Betty Baker, the site said.
"BEVO XIV is a special animal," said Ricky Brennes, executive director of the Silver Spurs and BEVO XIV's regular traveling partner. "He truly embraced his role and loved engaging with people at games and special events, and at his ranch â€“ where he will continue to live - he was clearly the leader of the herd."
BEVO XIV first became the mascot in 2004, when the longhorn was only 2 years old.
"BEVO XIV has served as part of a great tradition, and was a rallying point for Longhorns fans," said university president Gregory L. Fenves. "We all have warm memories of him as he heads in to retirement."
The Silver Spurs Alumni Association will immediately begin its search for BEVO XV.
